title: What will be the end-of-day closing value for the U.S. dollar against the Russian ruble on 23 August 2019?
preds:
Reposted do to my bad judgment looked at the question again because I had a GJ open client point it out thanks ... 
B.
And the day is still young! Will be checking at the end of the day if I remember that. :(
Very late to this one - reached 67 and moved down - had previously done similar move in Jan - since then 62.50 and 65.80 has been the range
Latest results from Random Walk model.
In time of doubt, buy a green back - ancient wisdom.

Argentina pulling dollars out of banks; argentine sells 2$ billion worth of dollars to prop up currency - thats going to continue.  Brazil sold $2.6 billion dollars to reduce the dollar real carrying cost  now at 400 basis points.   And logic dictates as long as the dollar is going up - keep doing it.  And still the dollar rises.  I think an unappreciated bi of the american oil boom is that the us is not sending out billions of dollars into the world in search of oil.     In the old days  .... what 8 million barrels a day times $50 per barrel:  $150 billion dollars  a year outflow.  On top of that Aericans are sucking in .. call it a trillion dollars a year in dollars in the form of treasury borrowings.
don't think the meltdown stops before aug 23
AS always, in the times of troubles, dollar wins. Dollar-ruble exchange rate should be going down after panic subsides, but just in case...
64.92 - recently lower global mkt risk benefits the ruble.

Looking at historical currency data and the corresponding price movements, it's tough to see how the currency would make any huge swings in the next 1.5 weeks. It's very likely to fall somewhere in the mid 65 range for the date mentioned in the question.
This is really a guess.  It would almost be best is WEG was a button.

In recent times the value of the US dollar to the Russian Ruble has gone down but with the crazy trade scene in Asia right now and for the foreseeable future I see the Russian Ruble staying fairly steady due to China and America in a trade war and Russia being a player in it but mostly watching what unfolds from the sidelines.
Latest results from my model given the recent dollar appreciation: 0.13 7.83 49.48 37.879 4.68

65.27
US 1/4% rate has benefited the USD.
Bin B down 4
Bin C down 6
Bin D up 10
sticking for now.    Out of the last 11 ruble moves over the last year, only 1 exceeded 3 rubles. I think percentage wise... 88 62-66; 12 66-70
Recent climb to ~$65 suggests need for more coverage of "Between 66.0000 and 70.0000, inclusive."
Showing the impact of political unrest in Moscow. https://www.economist.com/europe/2019/07/25/moscows-protests-are-inspired-by-the-thuggery-of-the-kremlin

Raising probability of 62-66 from Monte Carlo model (50% on good arguments by @Greyowlsova on likelihood of more stability going forward. https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/889277 and https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/874805

Bank of RF preemptively (before the Fed) decreased their base rate by 25 bp for ruble not appreciate too much. Ruble depreciated afterwards, moving from 62.00/$ upwards. The Fed predicted 25 bp cut is most probably already priced in. IMHO, only if the Fed cuts by 0.5%, we can expect ruble appreciating out of the band. Of course, this scenario excludes many unknowns - like Congress establishing additional sanctions on Russian debt or Putin's stroke.
the oil price driving the rubel down is a way bigger impact on the dollar-rubel exchange value than any screwed trump economic policy can have

The Russian Ruble has been scraping the bottom the Saudis flooded the Market with Oil. As long as the Oil price is relatively low so will the Ruble be. So it doesn't really matter HOW bad Trump handles the Economy the only things that can end the slump of the Ruble are high Oil prices or the end of Russian Plutochracy
Has been pretty stable for many months and talks re nuclear weapons undecided
Passage of time. FED rate cuts are now expected.
1 year average fluctuated between 63-68, current trend is slight upswing. Unlikely to change much more before 08.23.2019
63 right now, so should be about the same I would think.

Good Job report, higher yields on treasuries may indicate a stronger econ and stronger dollar going forward. 63.79 rubles to USD currently. Slight adjustment down for strengthening ruble <62, increase of 4% for 62-66, and 4% increase for 66-70.

Current rate is at 63.8219.  Trending down over the month with low percent difference overall. Less than 58.0000 - Unlikely that the Russian economy will strengthen increase the value of the ruble or USD drop in value relative to the Russian ruble.  More than 70.0000 - Unlikely the Russian economy will wane or USD increase in that much value within the time period.  However, it does seem more likely the Russian economy would trend downward due to global conflict.

Practically going back to my initial forecast - https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/874805 as ruble slightly depreciated (most probably, Iran and the US are not going to war - sanctions are on the other hand will be tightened), but IMHO will be gradually appreciating (OPEC deal is in the works, Fed may lower the base rate in July)
Update with recent data and adjusted by limited risk of significant depreciation.
My new forecast reflects good arguments for why the distribution should be skewed toward a strengthening of the ruble discussed here: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/874805

Daily and monthly variance over two standard deviations places it closing in 2 month's time between 60 and 70.  However, I've allowed some probability for outliers (biased toward the pessimistic from Russia's viewpoint) just in case there are large unexpected occurrences. The bias is in my view towards the lower end of the 60-70 band.
Will the SSC-8 issue have an impact in international markets? Moving to RUB depreciation. https://www.nato.int/cps/en/natohq/news_167179.htm

Oil prices rally as weekly U.S. crude inventory drops by almost 13 million barrels Saefong and Kollmeyer (2019) June 26, states that: Oil prices climbed sharply on Wednesday, as the U.S. government reported a weekly drop of nearly 13 million barrels in domestic crude stocks, reportedly the largest since 2016. “An eye opening [more than] 12 million-barrel draw in crude, which was 10 million barrels bigger than expected, should give support to the move” higher Wednesday, said Tariq Zahir, managing member at Tyche Capital Advisors. Given the big draw in gasoline and supply decline at the U.S. oil trading hub at Cushing, Okla., “we wouldn’t be surprised to see the $60 level get breached in WTI,” he said. “However, with the upcoming OPEC meeting and also the [Group of 20 leaders summit], we will see the next directional move on the results of these two events.” August West Texas Intermediate crude CLQ19, +2.37% rose $1.83, or 3.2%, to $59.66 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange after tapping a high at $59.93. It was trading at $59.24 before the supply data. The contract wrapped up trading Monday at $57.90, the highest front-month contract finish since May 29, according to Dow Jones Market Data. International benchmark August Brent crude BRNQ19, -0.44% gained $1.63, or 2.5%, to $66.68 a barrel on ICE Futures Europe. Brent rose 0.3% to $65.05 on Tuesday. Last Friday, the contract saw its highest close—at $65.20—since May 30 (Para 1-5). Saefong, M., P. & Kollmeyer, B. (2019). Oil prices rally as weekly U.S. crude inventory drops by almost 13 million barrels. Market Watch. June 26, 2019. Retrieved from
https://www.marketwatch.com/story/oil-prices-climb-on-reports-of-falling-us-supplies-2019-06-26

Ruble will depreciate due to geopolitical concernshttps://www.gjopen.com/questions/1210-what-will-be-the-end-of-day-closing-value-for-the-u-s-dollar-against-the-russian-ruble-on-23-august-2019?challenge_id=33#question_comments
personal knowledge of Russian history and the state of the economy

Updating https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/874805 - due to the US-Iran tensions and oil prices, the ruble is appreciating faster than expected. I believe, traders price in the worst case scenario all too often and dollar-ruble pair may bounce back, but they could be right.

The US Dollar / Ruble is the most popular pair to trade the Russian currency. There is no official symbol for the Ruble. Russia is the R of the four BRIC emerging markets and the eighth largest economy of the world. Russia is the world's leading oil producer since 2011, and the Ruble is therefore exposed to changes in global energy prices. The Russian economy is both a high growth one and exposed to changes in the global financial markets, which is why it was hard hit by the crisis in 2008 and 2009.
Strengthening relations with China and relatively peaceful interaction with the European Union will maintain the ruble stable near where it stands right now.

Updating, after some reading. The ruble vs dollar has mostly been spending the year between 63 and 68 with brief periods above or below that range. 5 year perfmance of the ruble reflects a more flexible range at 35 - 80. Long term trend is for the Ruble to weaken. The short term could be affected by economic realities, a fed rate policy surprise, or political happenings.

A global economic crisis or large scale war could drive the rate down towards pre-2014 rates.  Most likely will not return to that level but may drive it lower than 58.0000. About 2.5 of the last five years have been within the range of 62.0000 and 66.0000.   Currently in about a four month downward trend of the exchange rate putting it below 66.0000 and greater than 62.0000.  Tensions, or lack there of, leading up to next election cycle between the US and Russia, perceived or real, could swing the rate into a correction upward or drive it further down.  Very limited events where rate has surpassed 70.0000 in the past five years.  Near the election of Trump was an upswing with a maximum of ~80.
Ruble is at 63 to 1 dollar today. Still thinking thru what possible future events will move the value.

I perfectly understand the approach when some smart people take historical data and run Monte Carlo simulation or create models with it. With such approach you would think that the more data you get, the better your prediction - let's say, 5-year vs 10-year data set. The main flaw in this is that in 2014 Russia annexed Crimea, ruble depreciated from 28-36 range to 58-70 now (roughly), going through extreme periods of volatility. After that ruble has been depreciating gradually because of piling sanctions (American and EU) and relatively stable oil prices. But there is no other Crimea for Putin to annex (unless you believe the hype around small Baltic states). And Putin switched from world issues to domestic as Russians started to believe that Russia is a great superpower, but are wondering - why economy is stagnating and their living standards are relatively low? So I do not foresee high volatility of the past. The usual suspects are: price of oil (ruble spiked recently due to America-Iran tensions and subsequent increase of oil price), the Fed policy (as with all developing countries, ruble appreciates when the Fed decreases the basic rate and vice versa) and sanctions (no easing of those, but more may be coming - though in this case it will be "diminishing returns"). And of course, economy (stagnating, but this is most probably already "priced in"). If US-Iran tensions flare up, we can see ruble significantly appreciating. My guess it is of quite low probability. Most probably, US will increase pressure with sanctions and the oil price will be increasing within limits.  The Fed is expected to lower the rate soon - just nobody exactly knows when.  So IMHO ruble will be appreciating - but may not enough to pierce 62 mark- 63 level was met because of Iran and may not be sustainable at the moment. I may reconsider that statement No sophisticated data analysis, sorry.

Base forecast similar to @cafebedouin and @Emil but slightly different results (my model is much dirtier and quicker, for sure). 8% - 21% - 33% - 28% and 10% Main indicators seem to be stable: RTS index is close to 5-year max [1], inflation around 5% and expected to go slightly lower [2], consumer confidence in same levels as previous quarters [3], govemenr t running a surplus in 2018 [4] and central bank reduced the interest in 25 bps [5].
Suggestion is that there will be no changes, on the RUB 62.00 to RUB 66.00.
Special attention to Oil, as Russian economy is very dependant on exports. According to Vladimir Putin, Russia doesn't need oil prices too high, he is comfortable with $60 to $65 a barrel [6]. Chances that the price gets closer to $70 are high, so this shouldn't be a limitation.
So, only negative note is with GDP, as it only increased by 0.5 in Q1, but with oil price probably higher and money in the budget, it can be corrected easily. I go heavier to RUB 58.00 to RUB 62.00 and to RUB 66.00.
One question: why 23rd of August? I couldn't find anything about it, that could be relevant. [1] https://www.bloomberg.com/quote/RTSI$:IND
[2] https://tradingeconomics.com/russia/inflation-cpi
[3] https://tradingeconomics.com/russia/consumer-confidence
[4] https://tradingeconomics.com/russia/government-budget
[5] https://tradingeconomics.com/russia/interest-rate
[6] https://oilprice.com/Energy/Crude-Oil/Putin-Russia-Is-Fine-With-60-Oil.html
[7] https://tradingeconomics.com/russia/gdp-growth-annual

Outside view: I used a base rate of historical daily movements to build random walks as previously described. Result: [8.5, 25.6, 34.72, 22.61, 8.57] Inside view: Russia's monetary policy is currently dovish: "“The central bank definitely wanted to signal that it is joining the global monetary easing trend”Friday’s" [1] This will keep downward pressure. Amid potential loose monetary policy in the US it may just mean the ruble will stay stable rather than go down. Other arguments worth considering: "“The dovish stance taken by the central bank is consistent with inflation trending down from here and with no major worries that the Bank of Russia would cut too fast, the ruble will not move much”“Even with further interest-rate cuts on the horizon, Russian yields are still very attractive, due to the government’s strong credit profile, which will keep capital flowing into Russian markets”“The ruble will trade primarily on changes in oil prices, although it will not be as volatile as it was before the introduction of the current fiscal rule”" [1] As analysts have made good arguments for a reduction in volatility, I am tightening the distribution a little bit. [1] https://finance.yahoo.com/news/ruble-traders-greet-doves-russia-210000955.html

CME August futures estimate is 63.35 with a range of 56.60 and 73.17. If we assume an even distribution, it would put 8.5% on the lowest option, 19% on the top one and 24% on the rest. More likely, the probabilities are a standard distribution, so I'll concentrate on the middle option. Doing a walk through the trading days, today's prices and these breaks, I get the following: Last 5 years
0.086: Bin 1 - <58
0.297: Bin 2 - 58 to <=62
0.352: Bin 3 - 62+ to <66
0.137: Bin 4 - 66 to <=70
0.128: Bin 5 - 70+ Last 10 years.
0.049: Bin 1 - <58
0.264: Bin 2 - 58 to <=62
0.523: Bin 3 - 62+ to <66
0.092: Bin 4 - 66 to <=70
0.073: Bin 5 - 70+ [1] https://www.cmegroup.com/trading/fx/emerging-market/russian-ruble.html
